Hi everyone ‚Äî I‚Äôm hoping to learn from those who‚Äôve been through this phase.

I‚Äôm a PA-licensed PT, Schroth-certified, building a very small, part-time cash-based practice Reedy to Align, LLC. I offer telehealth PT in Pennsylvania and education-based scoliosis coaching nationwide, and I‚Äôm being very intentional about staying compliant and ethical.

I‚Äôve been doing the work ‚Äî phone calls, faxes, in-services, and relationship building ‚Äî but I still have very few patients, and I‚Äôll admit it‚Äôs making me a little nervous.

For those of you who‚Äôve successfully grown:
 ‚Ä¢ Is this early slow phase normal, especially for a niche specialty?
 ‚Ä¢ What strategies actually helped you get your first consistent patients?

I‚Äôd really appreciate any perspective or reassurance from those who‚Äôve been there. Thank you.

post_text:
Favorite in service/ free education class topics?! Would be a free 30 minute or less at a local personal training facility

Soreness vs pain? 
Posture? 
Lifting mechanics?
Targeted body part info (knee/ shoulder etc)?

I have only done one years ago for gymnasts so totally different demographic and really want to get my brain jogged on truly good topics and what im allowed to discuss in a free workshop like that. Obviously cant diagnose or treat individual issues - need a general topic to educate on! Thanks!

comments.text:
Unsolicited advice since these are what blew up my mobile gig. You can position yourself as the expert that can solve their pain point no matter the issue. My favorite presentation pitch is: 
Clarity: identify exactly what you are talking about 
Authority: why you
Problem: identify it 
Solution: what it will take 
The why: why you are passionate or why there is the problem
Opportunity: what they have the chance to be part of 
Next steps: how they can engage with you 
Essence: the feelings you want the to leave with 
Capstone framework. Just pitch them with confidence
I usually ask the gym owner or head coach/personal trainer for ideas.  They most likely can tell you 2-3 things their clients complain of or would be interested in.

post_text: Has anyone taken an accounting class that really helped their practice? I am looking into something like this on Coursera but would love to know of any others you may recommend!

comments.text:
I got my MBA and MS in healthcare admin which had several accounting classes in it. Most of them are more relevant for larger health systems not smaller private practices. A bookkeeping or a managerial accounting class may be a bit more applicable but honestly there‚Äôs probably better ways to educate yourself. 

A Finance class could be helpful  for not only your business but your personal finances as well. The best bang for your buck for your practice will probably be a marketing or operations class.
I got a MBA and the actual accounting class was the least helpful.

full_thread_text:

Hello everyone, hope all is well! I just wanted to post this out here on our alumni page. If there is candidate who may be interested please email us at **info@pinnaclemp.com**:

Job Opportunity: Physical Therapist ‚Äì Outpatient setting in a privately owned gym

Pay: $90,000-$105,000/annual salary depending on experience

Location: 2855 S Congress Ave STE C. Delray Beach, FL. 33445 ‚Äì Our HQ

Move Better. Feel Better. Live Better.

At Pinnacle Movement and Performance, we‚Äôre redefining outpatient physical therapy. We‚Äôre looking for a passionate and skilled Physical Therapist who thrives on providing one-on-one, patient-centered care in a relaxed, exclusive setting‚Äîfar from the chaos of a high-volume clinic.

This is your chance to work in a non-traditional, boutique-style environment where quality comes first, autonomy is encouraged, and your voice matters.

What We Offer:
* A daily caseload is 8 patients a day
* Opportunity for mentorship with OCS and FAAOMPT practitioners
* No PT mills, no 30-patient days
* A chance to work with a fun, supportive team in a truly patient-first model
* Flexible scheduling and involvement in community wellness events

What You Bring:
* Passion for helping people move better and feel better through movement
* Strong interpersonal skills and a collaborative mindset
* Excitement to be part of a growing hybrid practice offering a unique blend of clinical excellence and lifestyle integration

Responsibilities:
* Evaluate and treat patients with orthopedic, neuromuscular, and neurological conditions
* Develop customized Plans of Care (POC)
* Educate clients and families on therapy techniques and equipment use
* Complete timely and accurate clinical documentation
* Promote wellness and support community events/workshops
* Adhere to safety and infection control guidelines (OSHA standards)

Qualifications:
* Doctorate in Physical Therapy (from an APTA-accredited program)
* Current Florida PT license (in good standing)
* CPR certification
* Ideal Candidate will have 2 years of outpatient/private practice experience
* Valid driver‚Äôs license and reliable transportation

Bonus Points If You Have:
* ATC, SCS, or OCS certification
* Dry Needling, BFR, Spinal Manipulation, or Graston certification

Perks & Benefits:
* Continuing education credit opportunities
* Flexible schedule tailored to your lifestyle
* Career growth, mentorship, and leadership pathways

Schedule:
* Day shift (Monday‚ÄìFriday)
* Occasional weekends as needed

Ready to make an impact where your work is valued and your patients come first?

Email us with your resume to join a team that‚Äôs raising the bar for outpatient care in South Florida.

post_text:
**There‚Äôs been a lot of ‚Äúnoise‚Äù lately about physical therapy no longer being labeled a ‚Äúprofessional‚Äù degree by the Department of Education.**

Here‚Äôs the reality: **the public doesn‚Äôt care‚Äîand honestly, it doesn‚Äôt change a thing about what we do.**

Most patients don‚Äôt know (and don‚Äôt need to know) the difference between ‚Äúprofessional,‚Äù ‚Äúclinical,‚Äù ‚Äúterminal,‚Äù or any other academic label. What they *do* care about is:
* Can you help them move better?
* Do you reduce their pain?
* Do they trust you with their health?

That‚Äôs what defines us‚Äînot a classification on a federal spreadsheet.

While others get caught up in titles, labels, and politics, the real work continues: helping people get back to living their lives. The value of PT has always been built in treatment rooms, gyms, and patient relationships‚Ä¶ not in the Department of Education‚Äôs nomenclature.

Let‚Äôs keep our focus where it matters. The rest is just noise.

comments.text: When the APTA proposed the doctorate level of entry to our field it was to increase our view as a medical professional. I have been a PT for 40 years. The fact that chiropractors are viewed as professional and not PTs is demonstrating the  view of our profession. If it is about repayment of government loans, on average they earn less than us. As do theologians. I disagree so much with this post. If we are no longer allowed loans from the government we must seek out private funding. Profits going to banks and financial institutions. Will this lower costs, i hope so but I doubt it. Our issue as a profession is partially the way we are viewed by the public. Perhaps, Go back to the BS in PT if we are no longer professionals and stop saddling new therapists with unnecessary financial burden or perhaps unleash us from the burden of Medicare reimbursement limits and allow us to opt out. We should not need MDs to sign off on our POC. We should be fully autonomous. Then the DPT and the cost of this degree would make sense. Unleash us and allow us to be independent or change our degree back to a BS for entry level. During this time in PT history people still obtained Masters and doctorates degrees but they were  advanced practice in an area of study. I don‚Äôt know the answer but I do feel as a profession we should be questioning this and think hard about how we are perceived and our future. I would NOT make light of this decision.

What a small minded / ignorant comment this isn‚Äôt about the public.  Who cares what the public think they don‚Äôt know half of what goes on in the politics of healthcare. Heath-care and our jobs at the end of day is based on politics. This  is about the future profession and the ability for future healthcare providers like physical therapist, Nurses,and  occupational therapist to be able to afford going to school. All this is doing is elevating the wealthy to do us a please and again putting barriers for people of low income to pursue a better life. And not to mention how it affects reimbursement. I mean why would  insurance companies pay well for a non professional job? You tell me. This is what they‚Äôve been waiting for. 

people like you are exactly the issue. 
I‚Äôm fine, I paid for school easily - so what‚Äôs the problem. It‚Äôs not able the label itself, it‚Äôs how it impacts the future of our role as a provider in the financial health care system.  . 

Kick rocks.

Looking into having personalized scrubs made.  For those with DPT do you put  
Dr. (Name) PT,DPT or just (Name) PT,DPT  

Anyone ordered online for this or did you use a local company? Love some recommendations.  Font size?

comments.text: I worked hard for my doctorate, and am proud of the title, so I use Dr (name) PT, DPT. I see personalized scrubs, white coats, etc with both though. A lot of companies will embroider for a small fee when ordering.

post_text: Looking to get certified in vestibular therapy‚Ä¶.. What‚Äôs the best course? (In terms of cost, learning materials, travel, etc.)

comments.text:
Pitt vestib course and Duke/Emory course are the best.
Good to have a basic foundation for both. If you are new to the vestib world then def do some online medbrigede vestib courses then sign up for one these in person ones. 
If you already have some vestib experience you can directly do Pitt or Emory course.
I took a few different ones but loved the American balance institute.

full_thread_text:
POST: Looking to get certified in vestibular therapy‚Ä¶.. What‚Äôs the best course? (In terms of cost, learning materials, travel, etc.)

COMMENT 1: Pitt vestib course and Duke/Emory course are the best.
Good to have a basic foundation for both. If you are new to the vestib world then def do some online medbrigede vestib courses then sign up for one these in person ones. 
If you already have some vestib experience you can directly do Pitt or Emory course.

COMMENT 2: I took a few different ones but loved the American balance institute.

post_text: I recently took a dry needling class in atlanta and I practice in Florida. Can i start adding DN in my treatments or do i have to be supervised  every time I dry needle until I get certified or take additional courses ?

comments.text: In FL you have to be certified and then have 25 supervised sessions.

Certification first before you can needle as a treatment. Both UE/ LE courses will get the contact hour requirements. THEN it‚Äôs 25 treatments under supervision. Then you can submit for the DN tie to your license number. Once you get the confirmation that your license is updated, then you can needle independently.

full_thread_text:
POST: I recently took a dry needling class in atlanta and I practice in Florida. Can i start adding DN in my treatments or do i have to be supervised  every time I dry needle until I get certified or take additional courses ?

COMMENT 1: In FL you have to be certified and then have 25 supervised sessions.

COMMENT 2: Certification first before you can needle as a treatment. Both UE/ LE courses will get the contact hour requirements. THEN it‚Äôs 25 treatments under supervision. Then you can submit for the DN tie to your license number. Once you get the confirmation that your license is updated, then you can needle independently.

post_text:
Any recommendations for myofascial cupping courses. Ones that especially go over evidence based benefits, techniques, safety. 

Since I have a set I use on myself, I thought of incorporating it into my own practice.

comments.text: I highly recommend taking an FDM course through the American Fascial Distortion Model Association (AFDMA). Cupping is one of the FDM treatments, but an FDM course will help you more effectively apply cupping as well as delivering ridiculously significant and rapid results for several other patient concerns (check out the testimonial videos on my business FB or Instagram page for examples.)
If you have Medbridge, there are three courses on there Ôøº

full_thread_text:
POST: Any recommendations for myofascial cupping courses. Ones that especially go over evidence based benefits, techniques, safety. 

Since I have a set I use on myself, I thought of incorporating it into my own practice.

COMMENT 1: I highly recommend taking an FDM course through the American Fascial Distortion Model Association (AFDMA). Cupping is one of the FDM treatments, but an FDM course will help you more effectively apply cupping as well as delivering ridiculously significant and rapid results for several other patient concerns (check out the testimonial videos on my business FB or Instagram page for examples.)

COMMENT 2: If you have Medbridge, there are three courses on there Ôøº

post_text:
I've been a solo mobile outpatient provider for 5 yrs. Worked in many different settings for several years prior including neuro, vestibular, some ortho, home health, and more recently some pelvic health. I also provide mobile personal training services. 

I enjoy what I do but I'm getting tired of the driving and I don't want to go back to a clinic setting. 

I've been considering moving my business in a different direction. I've always been passionate about the wellness/fitness/nutrition space and I'm considering two ideas:

1. designing an online coaching program for the 40-50 and up demographic. I feel this is a very underserved population. I also have a personal training certification and I'm currently studying for my certified nutritional coach certification. I have a lot of pre-existing knowledge in both of these areas since they have been a lifelong passion of mine. This would fall strictly under the non-physical therapy category and would clearly be defined as such. 

2. My other and newer thought is to design written programs/guides that people could purchase. For example, mobility training, a beginner's guide to strength training, an intro to balance training,  intro to your core and pelvic floor, how to successfully achieve fitness and weight loss during menopause etc.  

I'm a big consumer of social media, vs actually posting, but I realize that for both of these I would have to do more posting, promotion and marketing. Also, because of my current algorithm all I see are physical therapy and wellness posts so it's hard to tell if this space is truly saturated or if it's just my algorithm. I'm thinking the latter.

I'm having a hard time deciding which route I would like to take. My mobile practice is doing quite well, so this has to make sense financially. But I'm really itching for a change. At this point I don't really need a full-time income, probably just half. But it's something I want to develop as I head into the last 8 to 10 years of my career. 

I think about this all the time as I have lots of time in the car ü§£ü§£.  I have a notebook full of ideas for content creation, and both ideas above but they do nothing just sitting there. ü§™

Would love suggestions and input from anyone who has done either! And maybe a swift kick in the butt to just do it already!

comments.text: Anthony Maritato tagging you because I would love your entrepreneurial take on this!
Britni Barber I wanted you to see this as #2 is my latest idea. I pmd you also.

post_text: So a personal trainer can charge cash to a client with Medicare for training but a Physical therapist with a personal training certification cannot?

comments.text: Use an ABN that states wellness, general conditioning is not a covered benefit.  Keep on file.  It‚Äôs good for a year.

You can. They just can‚Äôt have a physical ailment that your training could be considered treatment for. If it‚Äôs not skilled care (they finished a course of PT already) or they simply aren‚Äôt injured, you could provide cash based services that do not include a physical therapy skilled service/evaluation etc. you would want very clear signed paperwork to distinguish your services ofcourse. And look at your state specific practice act.

full_thread_text:
POST: So a personal trainer can charge cash to a client with Medicare for training but a Physical therapist with a personal training certification cannot?

COMMENT 1: Use an ABN that states wellness, general conditioning is not a covered benefit.  Keep on file.  It‚Äôs good for a year.

COMMENT 2: You can. They just can‚Äôt have a physical ailment that your training could be considered treatment for. If it‚Äôs not skilled care (they finished a course of PT already) or they simply aren‚Äôt injured, you could provide cash based services that do not include a physical therapy skilled service/evaluation etc. you would want very clear signed paperwork to distinguish your services ofcourse. And look at your state specific practice act.

post_text:
For those of you integrating yoga into your pelvic floor PT practice‚Äîhow are you structuring it? Do you bill it as part of your treatment sessions, or is it a separate service?

I don‚Äôt hold a yoga certification but have extensive training through various courses, and I feel confident using it within my scope as a PT. However, I‚Äôm curious‚Äîdo you think a certification is necessary? Have you run into any liability concerns?

Also, if you‚Äôre a mobile PT, I‚Äôd love to hear how you incorporate it in a home setting! Any insights would be greatly appreciated!

comments.text: Hey I recommend getting certified as well, but you can also start integrating the work while you get certified. Happy to answer any questions.

I incorporate it into my general PT practice.  Sometimes it is billed as treatment.  If it is for maintenance then it is cash based. I teach several group classes per week which has been a nice way to keep tabs on former patients, bring them back in as patients if something comes up, and they invite friends/family who usually end of becoming patients. I have also done yoga in homes as small groups or privately when I was more mobile. I only got my certification because I had time during the pandemic. Otherwise, it really is unnecessary. PM if you want more details üßòüèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

post_text:
To recertify a board-specialty‚Ä¶or not?

I would love some discussion from the hive mind to help me mentally work through this. 

I have a board specialty, and am proud of the hard work that went into obtaining it years ago, but beyond the initial boost in knowledge in my specialty area, I can‚Äôt say that I see it continue to pay off. 

I can think of LESS than a handful of clients in those years who said they found me because of the specialty or because someone recommended them to me because of the specialty. I can think of no referral sources who place it above location, reputation and relationship.

The costs are kind of outrageous. Over a 10 year MOSC cycle, $760 in MOSC fees. $470 each time for an every-3-yr required course, and an extra $200 in supplies if you don‚Äôt have them. $180 for an application review at the 10 yr mark, and $810 to sit for the recertification exam at the 10 yr mark (provided you‚Äôre an APTA member). That works out to  $3300 over 10 years. Just to have it!

This is having shades of a ‚Äúsunk cost‚Äù fallacy.

New grads come out, have a good argument about their schooling costing more and inflation and salaries doing what they do, and can start not far from where an established clinician with a board specialty costs. The board specialty becomes a non-factor as a bargaining chip for salary and pay discussions. 

Has anybody had similar thoughts or experiences? Has anybody decided, for themselves, to recertify? Why? Has anybody here decided NOT to recertify? Why?

Any help and discussion as I mentally work through it would be so welcomed!

comments.text: Thank you all so much for your input on this. Seems like many of you have reached the same conclusion I‚Äôm feeling but not ready to fully accept yet. This is unfortunate, and more unfortunate that board specialties are still promoted like they are as a gateway to career advancement, increased pay, etc.

All these are namesake nomenclature with zero financial benefits.... if you are a employee or employer in our field of practice ... the bottom for reimbursement is license to practice... 
Any PT can be equally knowledgeable academically without getting this certificates and still treat patients.... 

All these certificate BS is created by our lovely APTA to make money for themselves and those CEU companies .... as I was taught All this manual certification courses at my university while pursuing my masters and it is listed on the course syllabus...

As they say Doctors "Practice".... and everyone knows "practice make man perfect".

Can PTs treating Parkinson‚Äôs patients, share which they like better -LSVT and PWR? Thoughtson which you like better as a certification?

I was LSVT certified years ago, and while it‚Äôs a grest program we didn‚Äôt get to use the program as effectively given the protocol time line. We also only had a clinic with one certified clinician at the time so deliverying services with the protocol was hard. 

I‚Äôm a sole clinician again and wanted to see which protocol maybe more ‚Äúdoable‚Äù.

comments.text: I have both certifications and like PWR better bc it‚Äôs flexible and like the others I find it hard to do the BIG program as designed.

I am currently certified in both, but I pretty much exclusively use PWR these days. As a mobile therapist, it's just a lot more feasible for me.

To be very honest, taking even one person through the LSVT BIG protocol is exhausting for me -- mentally and physically.

post_text:
Hi there!  Are you a member of APTA?  Why or why not? Thanks! 

(Full disclosure, I am on the MN APTA board and talking to national APTA to learn why people are not members and how APTA can support the independent PTs. I have always said APTA doesn‚Äôt bring value to people like us but I wanted to hear from you). Thanks!

comments.text:
Not any more. 

I had payed APTA dues and multiple section dues every year since I started PT school in 1997. I budgeted to pay  over $1000 a year to APTA to cover state and national dues, Ortho section, Sports Section, Private Practice section, and Women‚Äôs Health section when my employers didn‚Äôt cover it. 

I attended numerous APTA annual conferences and CSM and paid for employees to attend those conferences too. 

I donated $$ to the Political Action Committee. 

I volunteered my time to serve on the House of Delegates in my state and assisted with State Chapter Task Force initiatives to fight to protect our ability to perform joint manipulation and dry needling. 

When I opened my own private practice in 2012 I paid in full for all my clinicians to have an APTA and state PT association membership and 1 section membership.

This year I made the decision for the first time in 25+ years to cancel my APTA membership -  their ongoing lack of support for those of us who are independent private practice clinicians and the true issues we are facing daily is utterly disappointing and I don‚Äôt feel hopeful it will improve.

Over my career I have only seen and experienced;
*increasing administrative & documentation burdens
*Inadequate & declining reimbursement rates
*flat lining of salaries for experienced clinicians not commiserate to their skill, training, advanced certification 
* reduced PT insurance benefits for beneficiaries 
*increasing productivity demands due to falling reimbursement and rising operational costs 
* plummeting morale from those of us that have been in our profession for any time working thru these challenges and burdens
*lack of action from APTA to do anything about these PT mill clinics that unethically schedule/bill in clear violation of payer contracts

There‚Äôs not much value‚Ä¶the ‚Äúadvocacy‚Äù has not been a priority. And because it has not been a priority,PT is becoming an unsustainable profession. How do you keep serving your community when business costs keep rising and reimbursements keep dropping? The amount of education, continuing education, time and volume needed to succeed are not reflected in the what you bring home at the end of the day and it‚Äôs almost like the APTA has never fully addressed this growing concern. And this is why so many of us have turned to cash based services which quite honestly makes the APTA largely irrelevant.

post_text:
Creating a continuing education course  and I have questions!

I was approached by a company to create a short online training course of 3 hours.  I'm aware of the state requirements in my state of FL and of CE Broker, who they use.  This company is based out of Washington. 
1. Is there a more efficient way to get approval in other states other than apply to each state individually?  To do so is cost prohibitive. 
2. FL does not have reciprocity with any other states. Is there a block of states who DO have reciprocity?

The other option is to just have course attendees self submit, but I'd hate to have them have to pay to do that for such a short course.

Any other options?

comments.text: Most other states only allow reciprocity if your requirements were not adequately equivalent. You can apply for a new license in other states it‚Äôs called an endorsement and it‚Äôs a pretty quick process‚Ä¶ However, it‚Äôs like applying for a new license.

post_text:
Hello, 
I was wondering if anyone has received personal trainer certification after became a PT. What classes you had to take and how was that process. Thank you in advance

comments.text: I got mine from NASM. I don't really need it as a PT. Then I got more certifications. Realizing I didn't need those letters. What I needed was a kick from my behind by Captain David Bayliff . üòÅüòÅüòÅ

I'm toying with the idea. It's not essential, but I do think there are some perspectives taught in personal training certs that don't get as much attention in PT school.

If I get one, it'll be with NASM, most likely.

Above all, make sure it's something you truly believe will be of benefit to your clients -- not feeding into some imposter syndrome.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hello, 
I was wondering if anyone has received personal trainer certification after became a PT. What classes you had to take and how was that process. Thank you in advance

COMMENT 1: I got mine from NASM. I don't really need it as a PT. Then I got more certifications. Realizing I didn't need those letters. What I needed was a kick from my behind by Captain David Bayliff . üòÅüòÅüòÅ

COMMENT 2: I'm toying with the idea. It's not essential, but I do think there are some perspectives taught in personal training certs that don't get as much attention in PT school.

If I get one, it'll be with NASM, most likely.

Above all, make sure it's something you truly believe will be of benefit to your clients -- not feeding into some imposter syndrome.

post_text:
Happy Sunday uncaged friends!!
I‚Äôm looking for info on how much a certified Pilates instructor might expect to be paid/ going rate?

I have one reformer now, so am considering hiring someone to do private classes when the clinic isn‚Äôt otherwise used, and perhaps expanding to 2 reformers in the future (semi private classes).

I‚Äôve searched online, but I‚Äôve also done that for physical therapy and the numbers can be way off in both directions.
Thanks!
(I‚Äôm in a small/ medium sized city in Florida)

comments.text: Certified by what body? I hold comprehensive certification for mat and apparatus through Balanced Body and charge $75-80 for a private session. $110-$120 for duet. Really depends on the quality/education/experience of the instructor. There are some crap ‚Äúcertifications‚Äù out there. And I‚Äôm in Honolulu, but when I was on the mainland there wasn‚Äôt a significant difference in pay.
Christa Gurka would be your person on this.

post_text: Just met someone who has severe diabetes and has been given virtually no education on a proper diabetic diet. ü´† I was googling for simple pdfs in english/spanish for diabetic education and basic food list of high vs low glycemic index.  Any great resources yall have to keep on hand?

comments.text:
I find that in a lot of these situations it‚Äôs not that someone in their path hasn‚Äôt tried to educate; it‚Äôs that whatever education has happened wasn‚Äôt given in an understandable format or the education was too overwhelming at the time to sink in. 

I‚Äôve been getting a rash of oncology clients with terminal diagnoses and when I or my colleagues start talking end of life prep and education on how this will effect basic mobility and ADLs they‚Äôre often shocked that this is the end. But I can see in their charts their oncologist documented educating them, ‚Äúyou are dying.‚Äù

Also if anyone has any recommendations for CEU on HOW to provide that education and coach through that decision making process, I would be most grateful üôèüèº

That is SHOCKING. So glad you're able to help them out with this crucial piece of their diabetes management!!

I don't have any resources to share. Hopefully more folks here will respond soon. 

If you're in the Doctors of Physical Therapy group, there's probably a bunch of folks there who have stuff, too

full_thread_text:
POST: Just met someone who has severe diabetes and has been given virtually no education on a proper diabetic diet. ü´† I was googling for simple pdfs in english/spanish for diabetic education and basic food list of high vs low glycemic index.  Any great resources yall have to keep on hand?

COMMENT 1: I find that in a lot of these situations it‚Äôs not that someone in their path hasn‚Äôt tried to educate; it‚Äôs that whatever education has happened wasn‚Äôt given in an understandable format or the education was too overwhelming at the time to sink in. 

I‚Äôve been getting a rash of oncology clients with terminal diagnoses and when I or my colleagues start talking end of life prep and education on how this will effect basic mobility and ADLs they‚Äôre often shocked that this is the end. But I can see in their charts their oncologist documented educating them, ‚Äúyou are dying.‚Äù

Also if anyone has any recommendations for CEU on HOW to provide that education and coach through that decision making process, I would be most grateful üôèüèº

COMMENT 2: That is SHOCKING. So glad you're able to help them out with this crucial piece of their diabetes management!!

I don't have any resources to share. Hopefully more folks here will respond soon. 

If you're in the Doctors of Physical Therapy group, there's probably a bunch of folks there who have stuff, too

post_text:
I've been thinking about branching out recently as I've noticed a need for mobile Parkinson's style programming like RockSteady or LSVT in my area. What would be first steps for this outside of gaining the certification/clearance to use the programming systems? 

Also, if it's the programming/groups that's being provided would it HAVE to be called OT and require an order/be billed as OT? Or is there a way around the referral process to make it more accessible? I live in Illinois and am fairly certain it's a direct access state per the state practice act but I could have misread. Ideally, I imagine running it like a gym model - offering groups and 1:1 at a specific "class rate" or "membership rate."

Thanks for any and all insight!!

comments.text: Honestly I‚Äôd look into PWR instead of LSVT- it‚Äôs more adaptable and modifiable to patients. I know a lot of personal trainers teach PWR classes‚Ä¶community word of mouth, no formal referrals

In order to officially offer PWR, LSVT BIG, or Rock Steady, you would need to take the respective courses to get certified.

To offer PWR as a non-therapist, you could get certified as an instructor. That track is geared toward the various fitness instructor roles, and can of course also be taken by clinicians.

Rock Steady is by default a wellness/exercise based certification. You can get certified as a therapist and could use the ideas in your practice, but you would not be providing the skills of your discipline. It would be a Rock Steady class. 

As far as I know, there are only clinician certifications for LSVT BIG. There is BIG for Life, though, which may be something other fitness instructors qualify to get certified in. I frankly haven't seen many of those classes, and there's a prerequisite for the patient/client to have already gone through and graduated from a full round of LSVT BIG.

...

I am certified in both PWR and LSVT BIG as a clinician. I have a mobile therapy model and rarely use LSVT BIG because it's exhausting to me personally, and because most of my clients would struggle with the intensity due to age, anxiety, orthopedic concerns, etc.

I plan to get certified as a PWR Moves Instructor, which is way more focused on building an exercise class. As a therapist, I highly value both PWR certification tracks. (I might also get a personal training cert.)

Keep in mind that if you do mobile THERAPY visits, most of these folks have Medicare or a Medicare replacement plan with out of network benefits. Unless you only want to work with YOPD or only want to do exercise classes, I strongly recommend you examine the rules for Medicare billing. The Medicare Billing for (Mostly) Cash Based PT, OT, SLP Providers Group can help with that area.

post_text:
Any lymphedema therapist here? I am trying to check if an American certification is mandatory or not. 
I am a foreign born PT and took an extremely comprehensive certification in my home country. I worked with it for a while too. Ive been a PT in USA for 10 years now and have not worked with it since. I am going back home for the summer and considering retaking certification. It is 1/2 off to retake, and when you convert our currency, 8-1, retaking it would cost me only $300. I am trying to decide if it is worth it though‚Ä¶ if I can work with it when I come back, sure. If wont count because it is not an American certification, then I may just not.

comments.text: I am! While is not mandatory, I will say it makes things tremendously easier and more informative. For example, MDs are more likely to refer if you're a CLT than not.
If you want to get referrals most people and doctors are going to ask if you certified.  It's not mandatory but highly recommended. Recommend ACOLS, Nortons, Klose or Ilwti

full_thread_text:
POST: Any lymphedema therapist here? I am trying to check if an American certification is mandatory or not. 
I am a foreign born PT and took an extremely comprehensive certification in my home country. I worked with it for a while too. Ive been a PT in USA for 10 years now and have not worked with it since. I am going back home for the summer and considering retaking certification. It is 1/2 off to retake, and when you convert our currency, 8-1, retaking it would cost me only $300. I am trying to decide if it is worth it though‚Ä¶ if I can work with it when I come back, sure. If wont count because it is not an American certification, then I may just not.

COMMENT 1: I am! While is not mandatory, I will say it makes things tremendously easier and more informative. For example, MDs are more likely to refer if you're a CLT than not.

COMMENT 2: If you want to get referrals most people and doctors are going to ask if you certified.  It's not mandatory but highly recommended. Recommend ACOLS, Nortons, Klose or Ilwti

post_text: What extra certifications do you all have that you have found compliments your traditional PT services? Personal training? Yoga? Meditation? Aging in place certifications? Others....? I am wondering if I should add something to my services...

comments.text: Only add what will educate you to care for your patients the way you want.  There‚Äôs no best certification.  I have very few certifications and I rarely talk about them.  If you‚Äôre ‚Äúwondering‚Äù then I‚Äôd say you don‚Äôt need anything.  If you see to learn a skill to help your clients better do that and don‚Äôt worry about if it‚Äôs certified or not.  Certified just means you completed the program to the organizer‚Äôs standard.  It attracts clients who gravitate toward name brands.
Certified Manual therapist. Certified Pilates Instructor. Two great adjuncts to Orthopedic PT practice.

full_thread_text:
POST: What extra certifications do you all have that you have found compliments your traditional PT services? Personal training? Yoga? Meditation? Aging in place certifications? Others....? I am wondering if I should add something to my services...

COMMENT 1: Only add what will educate you to care for your patients the way you want.  There‚Äôs no best certification.  I have very few certifications and I rarely talk about them.  If you‚Äôre ‚Äúwondering‚Äù then I‚Äôd say you don‚Äôt need anything.  If you see to learn a skill to help your clients better do that and don‚Äôt worry about if it‚Äôs certified or not.  Certified just means you completed the program to the organizer‚Äôs standard.  It attracts clients who gravitate toward name brands.

COMMENT 2: Certified Manual therapist. Certified Pilates Instructor. Two great adjuncts to Orthopedic PT practice.

post_text: Hi! For the golf PTs out there‚Ä¶ if you don‚Äôt have a brick and mortar place, do you do ALL your sessions at the course? What about if you plan to do some strengthening sessions? Can you shoot me some ideas on how/where you are providing services besides the golf course?

comments.text:
I started at houses, then a driving range, then rented gym space. 

If you can, get to know country club GMs, and do whatever you can to try and use some space on their property.

When I started I saw them at their house, which was difficult to sell at times. Then I transitioned to renting space at a driving range in their training area and it has worked great. 

Finding space in a gym or with a golf coach can go a long ways in my opinion.

full_thread_text:

COMMENT 1: I started at houses, then a driving range, then rented gym space. 

If you can, get to know country club GMs, and do whatever you can to try and use some space on their property.

COMMENT 2: When I started I saw them at their house, which was difficult to sell at times. Then I transitioned to renting space at a driving range in their training area and it has worked great. 

Finding space in a gym or with a golf coach can go a long ways in my opinion.

post_text: How would someone become a provider to offer continuing education credits to participants/students for a private company?

comments.text: If you‚Äôre providing continuing education to therapists, you need to look up the requirements for each discipline on their state board website. There can be a lot of specific requirements to meet and paperwork on your background and they usually want your CV and often a sample certificate that you plan to issue to your students. You‚Äôll also need a detailed itinerary of your course to submit. Each state and each board within a state have different requirements and fees to pay to become an approved provider for a course. Another option is to become an AOTA approved provider, which is more intensive a process, but then you wouldn‚Äôt have to apply through each state to provide your course to OTs, for example.

It‚Äôs state by state dependent, and once you are initially credentialed for the one course, some states have further credentialing where all of your courses can be pre-approved (as a CEU provider) but there are generally a few more steps including all educator‚Äôs CVs and research that is used to teach etc

full_thread_text:
POST: How would someone become a provider to offer continuing education credits to participants/students for a private company?

COMMENT 1: If you‚Äôre providing continuing education to therapists, you need to look up the requirements for each discipline on their state board website. There can be a lot of specific requirements to meet and paperwork on your background and they usually want your CV and often a sample certificate that you plan to issue to your students. You‚Äôll also need a detailed itinerary of your course to submit. Each state and each board within a state have different requirements and fees to pay to become an approved provider for a course. Another option is to become an AOTA approved provider, which is more intensive a process, but then you wouldn‚Äôt have to apply through each state to provide your course to OTs, for example.

COMMENT 2: It‚Äôs state by state dependent, and once you are initially credentialed for the one course, some states have further credentialing where all of your courses can be pre-approved (as a CEU provider) but there are generally a few more steps including all educator‚Äôs CVs and research that is used to teach etc

post_text: Has anyone taken any online courses from Institute of Clinical Excellence? I‚Äôm considering taking a course for CEUs and don‚Äôt want to waste my time if you didn‚Äôt feel like it helped your clinical knowledge. Thanks!

comments.text: I just took the Clincal Management of the Fitness Athlete foundations course and I thought it was really insightful. Each week featured: a lecture video with some drills, a weekly homework assignment, a zoom meeting to breakdown some videos submitted for homework and Q&A. The instructors are clinic owners that still treat patients and coach CrossFit  and are active fitness athletes themselves. Bonus you get lifetime access to the material so you can always refer back.

I havent, but if its CEUs and strength training youre looking for, I can vouch for my course, the 6 week Clinical Coach Challenge, which affords 30 CEUs and is within the same niche as ICE's courses :)

Need guidance for a certification:

Does anyone know if there is a nutrition certification that offers good clinical application and possibly also counts towards as CEUs for our license?

comments.text: Hey Brian, what do you mean by clinical application? Where you can actually practice the skills you learn?

Hey! I'm based in VA. I know CEU requirements vary state to state. Fortunately VA is pretty easy going. I took the ISSA nutrition coaching certification course. Great base information to utilize in a general clinical sense and also added a revenue stream to my business (that paid for itself in my first nutrition client).

I do know there is a Nutrition as Medicine course by PESI. I did look into it, and have heard good things, but decided I wanted to actually become a certified nutrition coach for the added revenue stream opportunity stated above vs just more information to apply clinically.

post_text: Do you need a certification in BFR to perform BFR? We have a new PT who is not certified in it. But I am. So I have all of the BFR devices and everything.

comments.text: I worked in a hospital based clinic where at the time only one PT was certified and she held an in service to train everyone who would be using it.

I‚Äôm no expert but from an effectiveness view point wouldn‚Äôt it be better to have someone certified in the exercise protocol with the cuffs (time worn, sets, reps, rests, pressure) versus just letting a PT use the equipment? 

They‚Äôd be better off sticking to the treatments they know how to use most effectively instead of wasting client time with something they aren‚Äôt trained to give best practice in. 

Also from a business liability view‚Ä¶ on the off chance there‚Äôs an adverse effect and records show someone not certified in the technique provided treatment how will that fair for your business?

full_thread_text:
POST: Do you need a certification in BFR to perform BFR? We have a new PT who is not certified in it. But I am. So I have all of the BFR devices and everything.

COMMENT 1: I worked in a hospital based clinic where at the time only one PT was certified and she held an in service to train everyone who would be using it.

COMMENT 2: I‚Äôm no expert but from an effectiveness view point wouldn‚Äôt it be better to have someone certified in the exercise protocol with the cuffs (time worn, sets, reps, rests, pressure) versus just letting a PT use the equipment? 

They‚Äôd be better off sticking to the treatments they know how to use most effectively instead of wasting client time with something they aren‚Äôt trained to give best practice in. 

Also from a business liability view‚Ä¶ on the off chance there‚Äôs an adverse effect and records show someone not certified in the technique provided treatment how will that fair for your business?

post_text: Are there any PT schools that are especially good at hand therapy?

comments.text: Do you mean continuing education companies? Or actual PT degree schools? PT school doesn't generally have a focus in one area. We learn a little of everything in a well rounded all-inclusive education,  learn some more specifics during internships and then usually specialties come later with continued education.

I remember at Columbia they had a volunteer trip to South America to do hand therapy with poor communities. The students got to do a lot of hands on work. But‚Ä¶ did I find the coursework on hand therapy that great? No, I am sure you can learn the same thing at another program or buy some books and learn on your own. My suggestion would be to go to the cheapest DPT program, set up your own  clinical rotation at a clinic with a PT that specializes in hand therapy and has that patient caseload. You can seek out your own volunteer and learning opportunities at any program. Then when you graduate yogi will have less debt and more cash funds to take hand therapy continuing education classes. I am sure you could also find a hand therapy PT residency, but IMO residencies with lower salaries are predatory. You are basically doing more work by studying, doing an A+ job for less money and I call bullshit.

full_thread_text:
POST: Are there any PT schools that are especially good at hand therapy?

COMMENT 1: Do you mean continuing education companies? Or actual PT degree schools? PT school doesn't generally have a focus in one area. We learn a little of everything in a well rounded all-inclusive education,  learn some more specifics during internships and then usually specialties come later with continued education.

COMMENT 2: I remember at Columbia they had a volunteer trip to South America to do hand therapy with poor communities. The students got to do a lot of hands on work. But‚Ä¶ did I find the coursework on hand therapy that great? No, I am sure you can learn the same thing at another program or buy some books and learn on your own. My suggestion would be to go to the cheapest DPT program, set up your own  clinical rotation at a clinic with a PT that specializes in hand therapy and has that patient caseload. You can seek out your own volunteer and learning opportunities at any program. Then when you graduate yogi will have less debt and more cash funds to take hand therapy continuing education classes. I am sure you could also find a hand therapy PT residency, but IMO residencies with lower salaries are predatory. You are basically doing more work by studying, doing an A+ job for less money and I call bullshit.

post_text: Any of y‚Äôall who do group exercise classes‚Ä¶how did you learn how to run them lol. Any advice welcome, any classes or CEUs I‚Äôm very interested in! I‚Äôm a PWR moves certified PT so I want to feel more comfortable structuring group exercise for people with Parkinson‚Äôs üôåüèª

comments.text:
Taking exercise classes yourself can give you ideas about structure, scaling, intensity, variety etc.  I participate in a small group strengthening program myself and now run three groups for 55+. I add more agility, balance and scaling options with my PT experience.
I also follow the Modern Management of the Older Adult section of ICE. They have great social media, podcast and cont ed content.

I‚Äôve done a couple courses from varying sources from the type of class I want to lead. (In the process of putting together a business plan.) What I find challenging is the variety of abilities that I‚Äôm *hoping* will show up to class and making it fun but challenging for everyone from an athlete to couch potato to wheelchair user. Because the group exercise classes I‚Äôve taken more structured around splitting up ability levels which 1) doesn‚Äôt work for chronic conditions like PD and the other Neuro dx I enjoy working with whose abilities can change on the daily and 2) that rubs my DEI(inclusion) training the wrong way. So not sure how that will go until I dive in, but hoping my PT brain will serve there üòÖ

As others have mentioned, every course I‚Äôve taken recommends making an outline to follow. So maybe I‚Äôll just flesh out the outline with options to increase and decrease the intensity.

post_text:
Anyone have any experience opening a business which provides physical therapy and personal training services under one umbrella? 
Looking to open a business solely for prenatal and postpartum Exercise as a licensed physical therapist and certified personal trainer/prenatal postpartum exercise specialist. Aiming to provide some group fitness style classes as well as 1:1 combination/crossover of the PT/personal training? For out of pocket only, no insurances will be accepted. Just trying to get a handle on any legal aspects of combining the two into one business if anyone has done it?

comments.text: I do this out of my home studio. The most difficult part was figuring out pricing. Some people do a combo of therapy and training, some do only one. So after a lot of headache, I landed on one cost for either. Every person gets a SOAP note. Documentation is simple, made my own templates in google docs.
Lauren yeah this is pretty common. Exercise can serve as an intervention on the PT side (if you want) and as a staple in a wellness program (if you want)

post_text:
Hi everyone!
I am collaborating with a family-friendly gym to provide a workshop and then an 8 week class focused on pelvic floor and returning to the gym postpartum. The goal being that at the end of the 8 weeks, participants feel comfortable joining the regular group classes without discomfort, leaking, or doubting that they can keep up because they will know how to modify movements. The workshop will be one hour and used to draw interest to get people to sign up for the class. 
I would love your thoughts and ideas on what should be included in either the workshop or the class itself. This is my first time partnering in the community like this!
Thank you so much in advance.

comments.text: Try to offer it at a time of day where moms are most likely to be able to find coverage for the baby (e.g., evenings) - this was a huge barrier for me postpartum if classes were mid day

Fellow PFPT here. I think in the workshop I‚Äôd hit the what‚Äôs common vs normal piece first (leaking, pain, hyper mobility, etc). I just took a class where we talked about teaching people how to palpate sit bones and pubic and tail bone to help visualize and feel for a pelvic floor contraction. I like that since you obviously can‚Äôt do a real PF exam in a group setting. 
I‚Äôd focus on teaching some general recruitment, coordination, and relaxation activities focusing on breath, TA, and PF (canister). Then you can build on that with functional movement in your actual class. 
This sounds like such a fun opportunity for you!

post_text: Hello all! What do you recommend as a clinical certification to make you stand out when opening a practice? I‚Äôm an OT and have about 10 years of experience but I feel like home health has made me so bogged down by assessment visits I‚Äôm having a hard time getting back to the reason I became an OT which is the treatments and seeing patients progress! I have a background in neuro but I would love to branch out to strength training and fall prevention /longevity area. Any guidance would be appreciated!

comments.text:
I wouldn't waste time or money on a clinical certification as your patients/clients/referral sources don't care about that. 

Invest in learning about: marketing, sales, automation.

I took the Modern Management of Older Adults 3-part certification series offered through the Institute of Clinical Excellence (PT on ICE).  It was a fantastic series that I really loved and would highly recommend.  OTs can take it as well.

I'm not sure how much a clinical certification actually means to the average potential client; however, I am planning to pursue the GCS for PTs because I want the knowledge.  I don't know if it will help to have those initials behind my name, but it won't hurt.  

So I think it really depends on what you want for yourself.  If you want a business where you are not really involved in patient care, then a certification probably won't make a difference.  If you want the knowledge, then do it for that reason.

post_text:
SLP question:
When a doctor says they have a potential referral for you but first wants to know if you are certified in Parkinson‚Äôs for swallowing and speech‚Ä¶

What do you say to them to explain? 
How do I say this without sounding cocky?

Even though I have not taken the LSVT LOUD courses, I am fully competent to use evidence based practice voice treatment to increase vocal intensity, interpret findings from a videofluoroscopic swallow study, train the patient on safe swallow compensatory strategies and/or diet recommendations. I also am competent in using evidence based practice techniques using expiratory muscle strength training to improve voice and airway protection at the same time to reduce risk of hospitalization from aspiration pneumonia, which is the number one cause of mortality in those with PD.

comments.text: Be cocky! Doctors aren‚Äôt afraid to toot their own horn

Simply let them know that, yes, you have specific training that involves the Parkinson‚Äôs pt as it relates to their voice challenges. 

You can answer confidently without being cocky üòÉ

post_text: Interesting experience at the dentist. My wife and I have been having TMJ issues so during my check up I asked if he had any Physical Therapists that he referred to for TMJ issues. He instead told me about two dentists both of which were very far away one of which he said was extremely expensive.Ôøº ü§®

comments.text: I would release the trigger points in the pterygoids to release the jaw. Also be wary of opening your jaw too widely at the dentist, and be conscious of your mental state and gritting your teeth so you can stop doing that.

Hi, this is super common. I'm a TMD specialist PT and my husband is actually a general dentist. Dentists only know the teeth unless they've hade advanced CE in treating TMD. Referring you to a dentist who treats it was a smart move, at least they knew to do that. Most dentists have no idea what PT can do for this.

full_thread_text:

post_text:
Here is an entrepreneurial story that I believe all of us can learn from:

There once were two bakery‚Äôs next to each other in my town. Nothing Bundt Cakes and Swirl Bakery. They sit less than 50 feet away from each other.

If any of you know Nothing Bundt Cakes, you know what you are getting when you walk in: Delicious cakes, ready to go, and a great experience. Everyone who works there is always so kind and ready to serve.  Ever notice how they even come around from the counter to greet you when you walk in?

Then there is Swirl Bakery: a fantastic bakery. They had cakes, cookies, cupcakes, scones, breads‚Ä¶everything you could possibly imagine. Everything was really good there. It was just an okay experience when you walk in, depending on who was working. 

So, what can we get from this?

Two things:

1) The power that comes from being EXCEPTIONAL at one thing. What is that for you and your company?

2) The difference it truly makes when you are greeted with a smile EVERY TIME you come in.

Now, I don‚Äôt know why they actually closed down. But, they were in our town for more than 10 years and I would be led to believe as a customer than 1 (or both) of the above reasons led to them closing up shop.

comments.text: We have Nothing bundt cakes here in Downingtown.  Love the cakes.

Clinical Mentorship. 

We all want(ed) it when we first got started and let's be real... if you're on your own as a clinician in a practice you miss being able to bounce ideas off of others. 

Residencies have their place but the reality for most residents is they work way more hours and get paid less than their worth for the HOPE that they actually get mentorship that may or may not ever happen. 

Image having access to pick the clinical brains of some of the brightest minds in PT, OT, SLP, etc. 

That's another PART of what we're building at Uncaged Clinician and want you to be a part of. 

Want more information? Sign up for the Uncaged Launch party for a free exclusive training and to find out more

post_text:
Hey everyone! Holding my first workshop at a dance studio in a little over a month. Do you have workshop attendees and/or the business owner of the place that's hosting the workshop sign anything in advance? I plan to have a "sign in" sheet with people to leave their contact info, but not sure if there should be any consent or written agreement signed, too. 

Finally, any tips on hosting an interactive workshop without PowerPoint or use of electronics would be greatly appreciated! Haven't done public speaking in quite some timeüòÖ

comments.text: Emily, I've been doing workshops since 2018 on various topics. I stay clear of ppt or any other electronic tools. I make a handout for everyone with a question that they can fill in as you go along. Use an attendee as a demo to show exactly what you do. You can sometimes pick out someone who might be a 5-minute miracle, but don't count on that being your closer. The closer should be a call to action without sounding like a used car salesman. Collect names and emails to build your distribution list. I always found 12--15 a good sweet spot for attendance. Much more it will lose it's intimacy. Less than 10 make it more personable for each person. Are you charging? Are you capping attendance? Not sure what you are doing or what state you live in, but doubt you need any sort of release. Sorry for throwing all this out there. Happy to chat- DM me

full_thread_text:

Finally, any tips on hosting an interactive workshop without PowerPoint or use of electronics would be greatly appreciated! Haven't done public speaking in quite some timeüòÖ

COMMENT 1: Emily, I've been doing workshops since 2018 on various topics. I stay clear of ppt or any other electronic tools. I make a handout for everyone with a question that they can fill in as you go along. Use an attendee as a demo to show exactly what you do. You can sometimes pick out someone who might be a 5-minute miracle, but don't count on that being your closer. The closer should be a call to action without sounding like a used car salesman. Collect names and emails to build your distribution list. I always found 12--15 a good sweet spot for attendance. Much more it will lose it's intimacy. Less than 10 make it more personable for each person. Are you charging? Are you capping attendance? Not sure what you are doing or what state you live in, but doubt you need any sort of release. Sorry for throwing all this out there. Happy to chat- DM me

post_text: Anyone have advice on how/where I could get CST certified (cranial sacral therapy) i am an IBCLC (lactation consultant) and see so many babies that need a little bit of tension relief. I would Lito be able to do it while i am seeing them instead of them having to wait weeks to be seen. Or at least get a better idea if they need to see chiro or not.

comments.text: Go with Upledger. I took their 1st peds course in the 90's. I've used it on babies ever since. It's like magic on the tiny ones. I think you may have to take the intro course 1st so you learn how to feel the CST rhythm before you try to feel it on a baby. But not sure if that's still the case

I‚Äôm a pediatric/neuro PT and am trained in CST through Uplegder. There is also a massage therapist named Lori Henderickson who does classes on infant CST. I think her class is good, but you need to know the foundational CST concepts first. She just talks about her infant specific protocol without going over a lot of the foundational anatomy and physiology.

full_thread_text:
POST: Anyone have advice on how/where I could get CST certified (cranial sacral therapy) i am an IBCLC (lactation consultant) and see so many babies that need a little bit of tension relief. I would Lito be able to do it while i am seeing them instead of them having to wait weeks to be seen. Or at least get a better idea if they need to see chiro or not.

COMMENT 1: Go with Upledger. I took their 1st peds course in the 90's. I've used it on babies ever since. It's like magic on the tiny ones. I think you may have to take the intro course 1st so you learn how to feel the CST rhythm before you try to feel it on a baby. But not sure if that's still the case

COMMENT 2: I‚Äôm a pediatric/neuro PT and am trained in CST through Uplegder. There is also a massage therapist named Lori Henderickson who does classes on infant CST. I think her class is good, but you need to know the foundational CST concepts first. She just talks about her infant specific protocol without going over a lot of the foundational anatomy and physiology.

Game changing CEU opportunity on December 12th. If you treat concussions, headaches, TMJ, craniofacial pain, cervical pain, or people with sinus problems you need to check this out. Taught by Cindy Stein Houck, this 4 hour CEU taught over Zoom will add another tool in your tool belt when serving your patients. Class will be in the evening so you don‚Äôt need to miss work and you can get those last few CEU‚Äôs in the bag before the end of the year.

To get information to register, go to [https://conquerconcussion.com/classes/](https://conquerconcussion.com/classes/)

To learn more about how this technique helps patients, watch this podcast by Derrick Hines: [https://youtu.be/jB8bh6irKKw](https://youtu.be/jB8bh6irKKw)

post_text: Alright all you Pilates peeps. I‚Äôve always been a big yoga person but today I took my first Pilates class and WOW! Such important pieces of strengthening. And I was so so happy to see this class was mostly seniors which is my niche. I‚Äôm wondering if you all have ideas of where to find more info, YouTube channels, best certifications to look into for the future, etc! Central Texas if that makes a difference. This instructor told me about STOTT certification in Houston if it‚Äôs something I wanted to look into in the future, but I doubt I‚Äôll end up wanting to be certified. Just looking to incorporate pieces into my PT sessions as I learn more.

comments.text:
I love the principles of Pilates and often incorporate certain pieces with my patients. My friend who is a PT is Polestar certified.
I recall it being a pretty big time commitment for her and she had to go travel for a few weekends as part of her certification for the practical portion.

I don't know if this helps much but there is a PT on IG Jill Koshak Johnson who has great content.  She really speaks to the perimenopausal and menopausal female population but you can apply a lot of principles to everyone.
I did reach out to her to ask about her certification she is Power Pilates trained, said they are more old school/classical pilates. She said Stott is also pretty popular but there are many options out there.

One of the best courses I have taken is by APPI Pilates. It was geared toward Health Care practitioners and took 12 or 15 of the most basic Pilates moves and showed you how to modify them for a lower level population.  

Hope that helps a bit!

For personal preference reasons, I am not overjoyed about it, but I am in the process of becoming Polestar certified, and I have to say if you're interested in Pilates for rehab, Polestar is the way to do it. Let me know if you've got questions.

can i bug any of you for feedback? 

I graduated my course on holistic hormones and am a certified functional hormone specialist now wooo! I made a quick rough draft flyer and faq ‚Äî 

Any feedback on my flyer and my FAQs? It‚Äôs just a rough draft for each, and for the flyer I plan on adding color / design. 

Also, any other FAQs i should add? Maybe ‚Äúhow long until i see results‚Äù, anything else? if you were a potential client, what questions would you have? I will post the flyer and faqs in comments 

Thanks for any input!!!!!

comments.text: This is such a needed area! I didn‚Äôt realize there was a cert for hormonal coaching. I‚Äôm going to look into that myself. I think your FAQ is great. For the flyer I would simplify the call to action at the bottom and say something like ‚Äúcall to schedule your 15 minute consult today‚Äù otherwise it looks great!

I would just make a simplified flyer educating your target population in what holistic hormone therapy is and the areas you cover. People don‚Äôt read lengthy fliers especially if they don‚Äôt know what it is about. I did t read the FA Q but hopefully you included if your services are covered by insurance or not. Good luck. As one poster mentioned I did not know that certification existed either.

post_text:
BOOTCAMP starts on Tuesday next week! 

We have had quite a few questions about UNCAGED BOOTCAMP starting on Tuesday, November 1st. We wanted to make sure you got answers, so that you don't miss out on this incredible opportunity to learn from the coaches at Uncaged Clinician:

 1) How long will I have access to the recordings?

A: Forever. On Tuesday, November 1st every person who has signed up for bootcamp will get access on their Kajabi accounts where the training recordings will be uploaded. That is evergreen and you will always have access to them in your account!

 2) Will I get LESS value out of the bootcamp if I can't be present for the live trainings?

No, not at all. Each Training will be a 60 minute training led by Josh Payne on the topics. Then, that will be followed by a 30 minute Q&A. Most questions asked will be directly relatable to you as the majority of clinicians in bootcamp are in the same spot of just starting up their business.

 3) Would you recommend reading another book or listening to some podcasts before registering for bootcamp?

Definitely not! The bootcamp is all of the information that you need to get started with your practice effectively. Remember: The answer isn't always MORE information, but rather how you are implementing the information. Bootcamp gives you all of the information you need AND the implementable steps necessary to take action on the information. 

 It's TIME to take action and set yourself and your business up for success! 

Our team is geared up and ready to help you starting on Tuesday night üëäüèª

Link below to sign up ‚¨áÔ∏è

comments.text: CAN. NOT. WAIT.
I have a question. I see that going over legal issues is included in the training. Does this include helping to develop a HIPPA p and p?

post_text:
Want to take your business to the next level? Follow these 3 hard hitting truths that I‚Äôve had to painfully learn, and you will find it.

1) Learn to ask for help. Do you have trouble in this area? Pride keeps us from growing our businesses to the fullest potential.

üëâüèªThe do-it-myself attitude is hurting you, not helping you. 

2) Learn to communicate effectively. When asked what do you do and why do you do it, do you have a compelling answer?

üëâüèªIf you don‚Äôt, this problem multiplies itself when you are leading a team. 

3) Learn to understand and be comfortable with your weaknesses. (Which yes, requires personal development)

People always preach on focusing only on your strengths‚Ä¶I think this advice can be harmful when trying to get your business to the next level. 

üëâüèªLots of times the main bottleneck in business is YOU as the leader.

comments.text: Oh this is so true!
So so so so good and true!!!!

post_text:
Earlier this year, there were several discussions here at Uncaged about what the APTA does or does not do for our profession. Listening to the voices of protest, concern, disdain, etc., made me want to create change.   

So when APTA Private Practice asked me to run for their Nominating Committee, I couldn't stop thinking about Uncaged and the mini-revolution inspired by this movement.   

I land on the side that the APTA is helpful, because it really has helped me:  
1) Make it affordable for PT's to serve those most in need.  
2) Saved my business thousands of dollars. 
3) Saved my heart by connecting me with amazing mentors. 
4) Gave me the confidence and a venue for speaking out about what is right and what is not in our profession.  

The APTA needs your voices. So if you are a part of Private Practice APTA, please consider voting for me. 
I'll work to magnify the voice of Uncaged Clinicians in shaping the future of small business in Physical Therapy.

comments.text: Thanks for serving!

full_thread_text:
POST: Earlier this year, there were several discussions here at Uncaged about what the APTA does or does not do for our profession. Listening to the voices of protest, concern, disdain, etc., made me want to create change.   

So when APTA Private Practice asked me to run for their Nominating Committee, I couldn't stop thinking about Uncaged and the mini-revolution inspired by this movement.   

I land on the side that the APTA is helpful, because it really has helped me:  
1) Make it affordable for PT's to serve those most in need.  
2) Saved my business thousands of dollars. 
3) Saved my heart by connecting me with amazing mentors. 
4) Gave me the confidence and a venue for speaking out about what is right and what is not in our profession.  

The APTA needs your voices. So if you are a part of Private Practice APTA, please consider voting for me. 
I'll work to magnify the voice of Uncaged Clinicians in shaping the future of small business in Physical Therapy.  
(Posted with permission)
[https://ppsapta.org/about-private-practice/leadership/Slate-of-Candidate-2022.cfm?utm_source=Informz&utm_medium=Email&utm_campaign=PPS%20Informz](https://ppsapta.org/about-private-practice/leadership/Slate-of-Candidate-2022.cfm?utm_source=Informz&utm_medium=Email&utm_campaign=PPS%20Informz&fbclid=IwAR3OHnRYlcw41XHIKfPcPxFEzy-WW9nV2gnAnpC60n6evvL14Wskyl081hs)

post_text: c'mon APTA!!  step up and protect our profession from this false advertising!!

comments.text:
I hate it to break it to ya, but the APTA doesn‚Äôt care. 

Vision 2020 was an absolute joke. They lied to an entire generation of PTs. Almost NOTHING was achieved. Lies and absolute deceit. 

I would love for all of us with DPT degrees to join forces and file a class action lawsuit against the APTA. 

These people should pay for the destruction they have done to an entire profession and the financial ruin they‚Äôve left thousands of people in. 

I wouldn‚Äôt give two rusty nickels to the APTA. 

And before anyone tries to ‚Äúschool‚Äù me on the good the APTA does, just know this, there are thousands of DPTs who feel like me. Heck, there are thousands of PTs from all education levels that feel similar.

Absolutely useless. 

I can‚Äôt even work in wound care anymore. Why? Because the APTA, once again, gave something within our scope to nurses. NOW, LPNs and RNs get ALL of the wound care jobs. 

Incredible. 

Save your gaslighting, virtue signaling, and ‚Äúfeel good‚Äù lecture for someone else. I‚Äôve heard it all over the last 10 years. ‚ÄúFeel good‚Äù stories and fighting dry needling laws doesn‚Äôt pay bills and feed families.

You want to actually DO something, here‚Äôs a start: 

1. Fight for wound care. 
2. Fight for increased reimbursements. 
3. Fight to expand our scope. And NO, I‚Äôm not talking about stupid dry needling. I want MEANINGFUL scope expansion - we should be granted roles similar to NP or PA. 

I would give anything to go back in time. Now, at my age, and with the absurd debt I have from the useless DPT degree, I can‚Äôt afford in money or time, to pursue PA or NP. 

Join forces with the AMA and the national nursing associations to create a bridge program for DPT to NP or PA. 

We should be able to pursue other areas and fields within medicine. We should NOT be chained to rehab and orthopedics. ü§Æ I am SO sick of being put in a box!! 

We should be able to do a 1-2 year residency alongside a PA or NP, in addition to minimal didactic work to fill in any gaps, to be qualified to sit for PA or NP boards. 

We NEED options! 

I believe in the power of movement as a first line of treatment for many conditions, but that is NOT the model for the American healthcare system. 

We need to figure out a way to work WITH and not against physicians, PAs, and nurses, or we will continue to be pushed aside until the profession folds. 

I‚Äôve had this gripe for a decade and a lot of what I predicted is happening (sadly). 

For years I‚Äôve talked about continuous decline in reimbursements. For years I‚Äôve talked about decreasing scope of practice. 

It‚Äôs happening every day. Wake up!
This is a private group so the APTA cannot view this

post_text:
There was a fascinating study that looked at the longevity of humans called ‚ÄúBlue Zones‚Äù by Dan Buettner and his team.

They looked at the highest concentration of areas of the world where people lives the longest.

Want to know the highest determining factor?

‚Ä¶

Yes, diet played a part üçé, but wasn‚Äôt the biggest factor.

Yes, exercise üö∂‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èplayed a part, but wasn‚Äôt the biggest factor.

The biggest determining factor was‚Ä¶HUMAN CONNECTION and RELATIONSHIPS. 

The study deemed that being part of the RIGHT TRIBE was possibly the most powerful thing you could do for your health.

And Healthy people build healthy businesses.

So, who is your tribe?

And are you surrounding yourselves with other business owners who are where you are at and also further along than you?

Well, Uncaged Live is the beginning of finding your tribe. I haven‚Äôt met or experienced a more supportive, loving, caring group of individuals in the healthcare space.

It‚Äôs time to change healthcare through creating a tribe that helps us to make the change that we want to see.

Will you be there? üëá

October 6-9th - Denver, CO ‚õ∞

post_text: Has anyone looked into becoming a practitioner for @classpass

comments.text: From what i understand they are looking for bulk discounts. I spoke with the yoga studio owner where I did the event last week and he brought them up. I wouldn't offer PT services because the way it is is setup, the more you charge, the less likely members will use their points to come to you. You are paid by ClassPass and they assign a # of points to your service. It's more for any wellness stuff you might want to offer

Class pass is for fitness classes. We used it for our Pilates studio to bring folks in the door and then let them know about all of our services. I would pick up one PT client every month or two from class pass folks taking Pilates classes. We did cancel recently as it just wasn‚Äôt paying enough to make it worth it. Precovid it was a good lead gen magnet but since not so much.

post_text: those who create courses what platform do you use? Please describe its pros and cons.

comments.text:
I‚Äôm currently using Heights Platform because I got a lifetime deal from AppSumo. (They have lots of deals ‚Äî beware of the FOMO marketing they use that makes you want to buy everything üòú) 

It‚Äôs good-enough for my first course and learning without having to pay monthly. 

Eventually I‚Äôd like an all in one platform that incorporates the email marketing, course and website‚Ä¶ but cost is guiding my choice currently. üôÇ 

Just remember you‚Äôll also need a good sales funnel to actually sell any courses. 

AND the biggest mistake I see is therapists making a course they *think* people want and need without digging into what the audience actually needs. 

So make sure you ask your audience what they‚Äôd like to see. 

üíó

post_text: Hi all! I‚Äôm doing a presentation this week (half hour) to young gymnasts (ages around 10-12). I have some content ready (stretches, when to use ice versus heat etc)- but is there any other glaring content you think is good specific for gymnasts? Any suggestions helpful! I was a gymnast when I was young so I do know that side of it, but I‚Äôm looking for other specific ideas I should talk about or good resources!

comments.text: I would talk about how food fuels performance.

Fueling for training, performance & recovery!  Maybe briefly touching on the fact that it‚Äôs normal & healthy to get a regular period, since they are close to the age it will/should start. Also, i like to use a guideline of age = absolute max training hours/week (so a 10 year old shouldn‚Äôt be training more than 10 hours/week), and that should include all aspects of training not just the actual gymnastics part. I can‚Äôt remember where I got that, I think from CSM when I was a new clinician.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hi all! I‚Äôm doing a presentation this week (half hour) to young gymnasts (ages around 10-12). I have some content ready (stretches, when to use ice versus heat etc)- but is there any other glaring content you think is good specific for gymnasts? Any suggestions helpful! I was a gymnast when I was young so I do know that side of it, but I‚Äôm looking for other specific ideas I should talk about or good resources!

COMMENT 1: I would talk about how food fuels performance.

COMMENT 2: Fueling for training, performance & recovery!  Maybe briefly touching on the fact that it‚Äôs normal & healthy to get a regular period, since they are close to the age it will/should start. Also, i like to use a guideline of age = absolute max training hours/week (so a 10 year old shouldn‚Äôt be training more than 10 hours/week), and that should include all aspects of training not just the actual gymnastics part. I can‚Äôt remember where I got that, I think from CSM when I was a new clinician.

ATTN: BOOTCAMPERS!! ü•æ

You should have just received an email about bootcamp starting up tonight with our first training at 8pm EST!

If you did not receive an email, it is most likely that you did not click the button that allows us to send you emails üò¨. So I wanted to make sure that you got the info here as well! 

Here is what the email said:

Welcome to Uncaged Bootcamp! We are so excited that you are here. It is going to be an amazing 4 weeks as we grow our businesses together.

First, we have our first training tonight! We will be covering legalities and logistics, and much, much more. Reminder: The training is TONIGHT, July 5th at 8pm EST.

Second, If you have been through BOOTCAMP once before, and you are receiving this email, you are welcome to access the live group trainings for this second round as well!

I'm looking forward to an amazing night tonight! And I am looking forward to being your coach for the next 4 weeks üôÇ
