post_text: California PTs‚Ä¶do we need any personal training certifications to be able to do personal training/performance/wellness coaching? I read our practice act and it sounds like it‚Äôs within our scope of practice ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

comments.text: Hi Luke, I am a PT and also a registered yoga instructor. I practice in MD but went to school in Cali so I‚Äôm somewhat familiar with the practice act there. I would say this is mostly a liability issue. We can never truly take our ‚ÄúPT hat‚Äù off even when training folks/ teaching group exercise. However, it does help to have a separate cert to help distinguish those services from your other PT work. So I‚Äôd suggest getting a NASM CPT or CSCS depending on your population. I‚Äôm currently studying for CSCS for this exact reasoning for when my yoga clients want to do more performance training with me.
I'm a CA PT. It definitely is within our scope of practice, but I also maintain my CSCS, just to cover all bases and help distinguish sports performance training from physical therapy services.

post_text:
Hello everyone! I am a Physical Therapist in Florida right now and recently applied and got my LLC to start my own business, but we are moving for an unknown amount of time to Washington D.C. As of right now, I am not planning to get my physical therapy license there but would like to see people under the umbrella of wellness still. I have my STOTT Pilates certification and am a certified life coach. I did have my NASM Personal Training certificate a long time ago but let it lapse when I became a PT. How can I do this, legally? Is there anything extra I need to do or be cautious of? How do I or can I market myself when people ask? If we do end up staying longer, I would probably get my license in Virginia and join the PT COMPACT but as of now, DC is not part of the compact so, I‚Äôm curious about how I could offer wellness services in DC, but PT in Virginia, Maryland, etc? 

This is confusing, but I‚Äôve let that get in my way too long! Thanks

comments.text: I've offered wellness for years. Above is correct. Also any forms before working w a client should clearly state this is not PT, it's wellness. There's not much else. Get an insurance plan or if you have just add wellness/training to it, it's cheap.

My thoughts. You can advertise your degree of a DPT (no one can take that away) but call your services all wellness services. You can not say PT though bc that is what denotes a license in our PT, DPT credential. When I tried to report someone in Michigan calling themselves an athletic trainer who wasn't an athletic trainer the board said they could only discipline a clinician who was licensed. So overall if your offering wellness and not PT and not billing for it I would assume you have alot less restrictions.

full_thread_text:
POST: Hello everyone! I am a Physical Therapist in Florida right now and recently applied and got my LLC to start my own business, but we are moving for an unknown amount of time to Washington D.C. As of right now, I am not planning to get my physical therapy license there but would like to see people under the umbrella of wellness still. I have my STOTT Pilates certification and am a certified life coach. I did have my NASM Personal Training certificate a long time ago but let it lapse when I became a PT. How can I do this, legally? Is there anything extra I need to do or be cautious of? How do I or can I market myself when people ask? If we do end up staying longer, I would probably get my license in Virginia and join the PT COMPACT but as of now, DC is not part of the compact so, I‚Äôm curious about how I could offer wellness services in DC, but PT in Virginia, Maryland, etc? 

This is confusing, but I‚Äôve let that get in my way too long! Thanks

COMMENT 1: I've offered wellness for years. Above is correct. Also any forms before working w a client should clearly state this is not PT, it's wellness. There's not much else. Get an insurance plan or if you have just add wellness/training to it, it's cheap.

COMMENT 2: My thoughts. You can advertise your degree of a DPT (no one can take that away) but call your services all wellness services. You can not say PT though bc that is what denotes a license in our PT, DPT credential. When I tried to report someone in Michigan calling themselves an athletic trainer who wasn't an athletic trainer the board said they could only discipline a clinician who was licensed. So overall if your offering wellness and not PT and not billing for it I would assume you have alot less restrictions.

post_text:
The transition of going from an employee to solo business owner generally pales in comparison to the transition of going from solo to having employees. Being and becoming a better leader is essential to long term growth and sustainability in business. 

I'm hosting a 6 week leadership development intensive starting next Wednesday to help you grow and develop as a leader.  

Want to join? 

Comment LEAD and I'll reach out with more details.

comments.text: What day and time (EST) is this course?

Let‚Äôs go! I‚Äôve got something to say on this: if you are a solopreneur, you are the CEO. You must be able to lead yourself before you can grow enough to be able to lead others. Leading others (and also raising children which is also leading others) is the most challenging thing you will ever do. Grow yourself to be able to effectively lead others. Lots of people talk about having great teams where they can truly be the CEO and be able to see less patients‚Ä¶well, believe me, you better learn how to lead others‚Ä¶and it starts by learning how to lead yourself. 

I can‚Äôt think of anyone better to lead this program in Kevin DeGroot. Learn from him. He‚Äôs too humble to say it but he does a damn good job at leading his team at T-Zero. Being able to learn from him and how he is able to lead from a perspective of faith is invaluable, and possibly one of the most important things that people need to learn. We need more leaders, and leaders go first.
